text: OK. Good morning, everyone. Happy spring. Welcome to EE259.

My name is Reza. I'll be teaching principles of
sensing for autonomy this quarter,

which is a brand new course. So this is the first offering. The course has been two
years plus in the making.

So I'm pretty excited to
offer it this quarter.

And my goal for
today is to give you a high level overview
of what the course is

about, and motivated-- some of the ideas
behind the course

and why I think this is an
important course to teach, and also we'll go over
some of the course logistics, typical
stuff, and then

hopefully get to start
some of the actual material for the course. So with that, we can get
started with the overview.

So as I said, this is
a brand new course, and the core idea
of E259 is for us

to develop a foundational
understanding of how different sensors that are
used for robotic autonomy work?

And by foundational,
what I mean is we are going to start from very
basic physics principles of how

sensing works in
different scenarios and with different
pieces of hardware. So we're going to
start with things

like forces, electromagnetic
fields, photons, as basic

as that. And then from
there, we basically learn the fundamental
principles of operations

of different sensors. Then we use that
understanding to develop

what we call signal models
for different sensors. And also how to use these signal
models to process the signals

that we receive from
different sensors, and how these algorithms
work that basically translate

the raw signals that you
get from different sensors into something that is an
understandable representation

of the environment. Things like images
or point clouds, how are these generated? And finally, we go all the
way to develop a system level

understanding of
different sensors. And at the system
level, then we talk

about things like
trade offs that can affect the performance of
different sensors, how they can

be complementary to each
other in different scenarios, and so on.

Now, the big question is,
why is this important and specifically, why should
you care about this?

So to motivate the discussion,
I want to basically first talk

about what is autonomy, which
is in the title of the course? So principles of
sensing for autonomy.

So in one sentence,
basically, autonomy is a collection of
ideas and technologies

that brings AI to
the physical world. So if you look at
the past 20 years,

there's been really an explosion
of AI tools and applications

around us. But most of it today is just
confined to the software domain

or the virtual world. So things like
ChatGPT, now GPT 4, all these different models
that do amazing things,

very, very sophisticated,
but there is still quite limited to the software domain.

Now, the idea of
autonomy is, how do we bring AI to the physical world?

How do we enable AI to interact
with the physical world? And this is basically what the
job of autonomous robotics is.

And to be able to bring AI to
the physical world, two things

need to happen. So these robots need to be
able to navigate the world, and also interact with it. And that's the job of autonomy.

Mars rovers, robotaxis,
drones, humanoid robots. These are all
different embodiments

of autonomous robotics, but
the idea or the principles

are going to be the
same across the board. So how do we bring AI
to the physical world?

And the foundation
of autonomy is going to be based on sensing.

But what's counterintuitive
and interesting is, one thing we learned
in the past 20 years

is that autonomy is really,
really a difficult problem. So there's been a lot of
decades of interesting research

and development and
quite a lot of progress, but still, we are
not at the point where we see
unconditional scalable

autonomy all around us. It's not like we're surrounded
by these amazing robots that do lots of interaction
with the physical world.

We're seeing very
interesting, I guess, what we call demos or
proofs of concepts. Like if you go to San Francisco,
you see these robotaxis

from different companies
going around the blocks, but still, it's
very, very limited.

So I still consider us at the
very early days of autonomy.

Unlike, I guess, the AI, we
are now much more progress in the virtual domain.

But in the physical domain,
we are still pretty early on. And here is one of
my favorite quotes

from Hans Moravec who did his
PhD in the Stanford in the 70s.

And this is referred to
as the Moravec's paradox. And it says, it's comparatively
easy to make computers accept

that adult level performance on
intelligence tests or playing checkers, and difficult
or impossible to give them

the skills of a
one-year-old when it comes to perception and mobility. And I think he said this
somewhere in the 70s,

and it still is
quite relevant today. And the picture you
see on the right

is actually the picture of
him with what at the time was modestly called
the Stanford card.

So this is from 1977. And this was one of the
very, very first autonomous,

I guess, robots, if you will. It was tele-operated,
so it wasn't really autonomous at the time.

But it had the cutting
edge technology of the time, which was a very
basic camera and some radio

communication system. If you go on the web and
search for a Stanford card, you would see-- you can
find actually videos

from the 60s of the
Stanford car just driving around the campus,
which is pretty fun.

it's not too far from this room
actually where this was taken. OK. So to enable autonomy, sensing
is really the foundation.

If these robots cannot
sense the environment, there's no hope of enabling them
to really navigate and interact

with the world. So that's really
the main reason why

sensing is such an important
thing to robotics and autonomy. And to be able to navigate
and interact with the world,

there's-- you can break it down into
three functions basically. And that's also like
how us humans navigate

and interact with the world. The first is, you need a map. You need to know
what's around you,

and that's what we call a map. So either a map
is given to you-- somebody has mapped
the environment

and they give it to you, and
that's the map, or if not, you have to map it yourself. And to map the
environment yourself,

you need some sensors. You need to gather signals
from the environment and figure out
what's around you.

The second thing that needs
to happen is localization. So you have to find out
where you are on the map.

It's not just enough
that you have a map. You need to know
where you are on it. And finally, you
need what we call

odometer tree,
which is basically, how you are moving on this map? So you know where you
are, but also, you're

going to be dynamic. If you're interacting with the
world, if you're navigating it, you're going to be moving. So that's your velocity,
your trajectory,

how you're moving in
there, that's odometry. So these are like the three
main things that need to happen.

And depending on what
you are trying to do, what kind of
interaction you want

to do with the
environment, there's going to be different
requirements for these different functions.

For example, if you're
just in a new city, you're trying to find
your way around the city

and go from some
point A to point B and this is a new city you're
not familiar with, probably

the first thing you do,
you take out your phone, you open your
favorite maps app-- Google map or whatever,
and you localize yourself.
Like, where am I in this city? And that's a pretty good start.

It tells you globally on
the city where you are, and you can also
find your destination

and get a rough idea of how you
should basically move to get

to the point you want to be at. But the level of detail you
get from, say, a Google Map

is not enough to help you
fully navigate your way. So if you just
look at your phone

and pay no attention
to your environment, there's no way you can safely
get to your destination. You're going to bump to people.

You're going to get hit by car. You need a much more
detailed local representation

of what's around you to be
able to really safely navigate to where you want to be at.

So you see there's-- here, you have two
different levels of mapping. So your Google Map gives
you the global course

map of what's around you, and
then your own sensors, which

is your eyes and
your ears, build a much, much more detailed
map at a much smaller scale

around you. So we need both to be
able to fully navigate. And that's why, again, if
you didn't have your sensors

or somehow if you could
just get the Google Map information into the brain and
you shut your eyes and ears,

there's no way you can safely. Navigate same is
true about robots. So we can't just somehow
download a map into a robot

and hope that it will safely
navigate the environment and interact with it. They need sensors and they
need to dynamically map

out their own environment
in very high detail. OK. So here's one example of just--
this is taken from a Tesla

vehicle, and this is like a
visualization of the local map

so it has cameras around it. And you see it's a
small scale, so it only

sees a few blocks around the
car, but it's very detailed. It can map out all
the cars around it,

how every car is moving,
and it can localize itself

within the map. So that's the ego
vehicle you see here.

So that's the localization
within the map that it has generated. And also, it has some
idea of how it's moving,

and that's the odometer output. So based on, again,
the inputs that it

gets from this different
sensors and also knowledge of the vehicle
dynamics, it can also

do pretty accurate odometry. And that's how a Tesla navigates
basically and moves around.

Of course, we all
know it's not perfect, and that's, again,
why this course exists

because if this was
a solved problem, we did not have
to talk about it. So what kind of sensors
are used in autonomy?

It depends on the specifics
of the application.

Everything starts with
sensing, but what exact sensors are required, it depends on the
specifics of the application.

Autonomous vehicles
are just one example. This is not a course
about autonomous vehicles,

but it's just one of those,
I think, most common examples that we have all heard
about and maybe seen them

and maybe even
interacted with them. So we're going to see a
lot of examples about AVs.

But all the principles applies
to other types of autonomous

systems and the types of
sensors also that are used are pretty common between AVs
and other types of autonomous
robots. So here, there's two examples. One is from 2005.

And this car here,
this is called Stanley. And this was fully
developed and operated

by a team of
Stanford students led by Sebastian Thrun at the time.

And there was this thing called
the DARPA Grand Challenge in the 2004 and 2005, which
was a challenge for basically

equipping vehicles with
technologies that would enable

them to autonomously navigate. And there was two
parts to the challenge. There was one part in the desert
where this picture was taken,

and then there was
an urban challenge. And the Stanford vehicle--

Stanley came up on top. I think 2004 when the first
DAPRA Grand Challenge happened,

everybody failed. Like, nobody was
able to complete it. And then the second year,
Stanford came on top.

And here, you see like what
sensors were used at the time. So these big bulky ones--
and there's five of them.

These are LiDARS, and then
you have smaller cameras. It's hard to see, but
cameras are mounted there.

These yellowish
things are radars. You see GPS. These are just the
antennas for the GPS

these disk-looking things,
and then the actual GPS chip is mounted somewhere
in the cabin.

And then there's
inertial sensors that is also inside
the cabin mounted near the rear axle
of the vehicle.

There's also sonar
or ultrasonic sensors that are integrated into
the bumper of the vehicle

at the front and back. So this was 2005. And then fast forward 18
years, you go to San Francisco,

you see these things from
Waymo or other companies,

and the exact same kind
of sensors are still used. I mean, these are
much better sensors.

I mean, the technology
is progress many years. But from an architecture point
of view, it's almost identical.

So you see your LiDAR up top. There's radars and
cameras around it. There's corner radars.

Sonar still in the bumper. IMU and GPS is also integrated
somewhere in the cabin.

So again, autonomy
is still not solved.

For 20 years, we've been using
the exact same architecture. And the question is, why?

Why is it that after 20 years,
we're still not quite there with autonomy?

And again, it goes back
to what I said earlier, that it's a very difficult
problem to solve.

And I'll talk a little
bit more about it. But for us, what matters is
that from a pure sensing point

of view, there's six sensors
that kind of give you

all the information
you could possibly gather from the environment. And we need to really understand
these sensors from physics

principles in order to
be able to really tackle this problem of autonomy.

So the six sensors
are listed here. Again, it's GPS. And there's inertial sensors,
which includes accelerometers

and gyroscopes. There's sonar or ultrasonic
sensors, there's radar,

there's LiDAR, and
there's cameras. And you don't need
to know anything about any of these sensors,
maybe a third of them.

GPS maybe is the most
famous one or camera. But we're going to
start from scratch

and basically show you from
first physics principles all the way to system level,
how these sensors operate,

how the algorithms that
process the signals operate, how the hardware is designed,
and how this software works
for them. Now, why is study sensors?

So I think we said, OK,
sensing is important. Autonomy is a big
problem, still open.

Sensing is at the core of it
or at the foundation of it for autonomy. So we need to
understand sensing,

but why study sensing
in such detail?

Why start from
physics principle? Why can't we just have some-- I don't know, phenomenological
model or some black box model

of, this is a camera. It just gives me
pictures, and I just need to use these picture
frames or video frames

to make sense of the world. Or here's a LiDAR. It gives me a point cloud,
which is this 3D representation

of the world, and then I
need to write algorithms or to train machine
learning models or whatnot to make this
and use this and make

sense of the world. Well, so yeah,
one might ask, why go so deep in
studying the sensors?

And again, it goes
back to, I think, the fact that we're still at
the very early days of autonomy.

If you look at any
other technology, say personal computers
or the internet,

at the very early
days, there's a lot of things that are
not figured out yet.

There's no reference
system design. So if you go back-- I don't know, like 60, 70
years, personal computers

were not quite like figured
out at the architecture level the way they are today.

So people who are the
researchers and engineers who are developing
these technologies,

they need to have very
deep understanding of how these systems
operate across the board.

You cannot just be like-- I don't know, 67 years ago,
software engineers or software

engineering was
very, very different from what it is today. Today, you can be a
software engineer, and you can almost not know
much about how a CPU works

or how GPU works or the
hardware architecture of a personal computer. You can just focus on your
application development

and be an amazing
software engineer. And that's because throughout
the years, all this development

that has happened,
the architecture has been completed. There is abstraction layers
that have been developed

like the operating system and
whatnot that completely can abstract out the details
of how the hardware works

from, say, the
application layer. Now, in robotics, we
don't have that today. We don't have a reference
design for an autonomous

robot with everything
figured out and like the abstraction
layer as an operating system,

and then people can just go
develop robotic applications on top of it. That does not exist today.

So today, if you want to really
work on autonomous robotics, we are still in the early
days, and you really

need to have very deep
understanding of how every piece of the system works.

And again, sensing is
at the foundation of it. So that's why we need
to really develop

this deep, deep understanding
of how sensing works to be able to eventually
hopefully solve

the heart problem of autonomy. So again, many challenges
still remain to be solved.

Some of these require rethinking
of how sensing and perception are done.

Some challenges require
maybe entirely new sensor designs that nobody
has thought of yet.

And we'll see some of those
ideas throughout the course. And some of these challenges
require new algorithms

that process the sensor
data in a different way to be able to, say, perceive
the world in certain conditions

that are not quite
possible right now. And none of these is
possible if we only

understand sensing and
sensors at a black box level. So we really, really-- if
you want to focus and solve

the hard problems of
autonomy, I believe we need a deep understanding
of sensing at physics level
almost. OK. Any questions so far?

No? All right. So here's just one
example, just for fun.

So let's compare a autonomous
drone and a bat, OK? So if I ask you,
which of these two

has more capable
sensing hardware? I think we can all agree
that the drone has much more

sophisticated sensing hardware. It can have HD cameras, radars,
LiDARS, GPSs, and whatnot.

Versus the bat,
you might know, it has one of the most primitive
sensing hardware, which is just

two big ears, and it
sends these sound waves,

and it uses echolocation. So basically, from the
echoes of these sound waves

from the environment, it tries
to figure out what's around it. Super primitive.

OK. Now, who is better at autonomy? I think we can also
agree that is much, much,

much better at autonomy
than our autonomous drone. It can navigate at
very high speeds

in these sophisticated
cave systems where there's almost
no light and lots

of intricate structure in the
environment where our drone-- I mean, it can't even navigate
a building like this yet.

So why is that the case? So I can't fully answer ti, but
there's certain observations

that might help clarify this. One is that the
bats brain, it has

evolved these very
complex signal models that really leverages
all the information that

is available from these
very primitive signals that it detects from
the environment, OK?

So yes, the sensing
hardware is pretty basic, but there's a ton of information
in that very basic signal,

which is just an echo
coming from the environment. And if you train the
models in the brain,

you can actually get very
sophisticated sensing

and perception out of it. Versus the way our
drone works today-- again, this is all today.

Hopefully, in a few
years, the drone is going to outperform the bat.

Is that today, we treat
sensors as black boxes, and we get these already
processed sensor outputs

as images or point
clouds, and we just try to make sense of
the world using that. So a lot of the intricate
detailed information

and the physics of
the signal is lost in the process of translating
it from the physical world

to these representations. And I think that really
becomes a bottleneck in how well we can do autonomy.

So the thinking here is
that we can get much more out of the sensors if their
operation principles are fully

understood and factored into
downstream algorithms, which is one of the core
ideas of this course.

OK. One more example. This is more of like
a historical note,

but you might be familiar with
this idea of high dynamic range or HDR photography.

Nowadays, most of
the phones do it. But back in the day,
like in the early days

of digital photography-- even the best digital
cameras out there,

if you just use them in what
we call the point and shoot mode, which is fully
automatic mode,

and then you try to take a
picture of the environment where there is a lot
of dynamic range,

so you have very bright
stuff and very dark stuff, you would either
get an image that is underexposed or overexposed.

So here on the left, you see
three examples of this scene. The top one is pretty dark.

Only this building looks
nice and everything else is pretty dark.

You can't really make
sense of what's around it. And the overexposed
version is this.

You get all the details in
the sky, some of the details and the buildings-- the side buildings, but
this middle main building

is completely washed
out and overexposed. And the best the
cameras could do

is try to find a middle ground
with setting their exposure limits and give you
something like that.

So that was the best a digital
camera would give you say-- I don't know, 10
or 15 years ago.

And then somebody
or a group of people came up with this idea of high
dynamic range photography,

which was, why not take
three pictures very quickly

and then have these
algorithms that figure out which part of each image
has the amount of exposure

and intelligently combine them
to build this beautiful image, which is the HDR
image, and really has

the best of all three images
and even more than that. And all the details in the
sky the middle building

and the side buildings
are pretty clear in it. So I mean, it sounds like not
a super sophisticated idea,

and it's not, except some of the
details of the algorithms that go into it.

They're pretty clever. But nobody would have come
up with an idea like this,

as simple as it is, if they
didn't know the basics of image

formation and
things like what is exposure, what is saturation,
what is tone mapping,

and so on? So really, you need to know the
physics of how a camera works and the physics
of image formation

to be able to come up with
an idea like HDR photography. And again, this is super,
super simple example,

but the idea is to
motivate like why it's important to know how
sensors work deep down.

And with a black box
approach to sensing, we would not have had
HDR photography today

and we would still be working
with these overexposed or underexposed images.
OK. Questions. No? All right. Let's continue.

OK. I also want to-- just a few minutes to spend
on basically the bigger--

what we call the autonomy stack. So we talked about sensing. But to do autonomy, you
need more than just sensing.

And again, this is not the
main focus of the course, but I think it's
important to know we're sensing is in the bigger
picture of an autonomous

system. So as we said, for
any autonomous system, it starts with sensing,
and the sensing

is the connection of the
hardware and the associated signal processing
algorithms that

try to basically sense the
world and provides outputs like point clouds,
images, or maybe things

like acceleration and
velocity and position. So these are the kinds of
outputs you get from sensing.

Then from sensing, the
next step that-- and again, this is the conventional
way of doing autonomy,

is what we call perception. So the job of
perception is, it's a collection of
algorithms and machine

learning models that
tries to extract meaning from the
outputs of the sensors.

What does it mean? What's around this? And the types of functions
that are typically

considered parts of
a perception system are things like fusing
different sensors producing

these odometries. Recognizing different
objects, estimating

trajectories, tracking different
dynamic assets in the scene, and so on and so forth.

Then from there, the next
step is what we call planning. So you have sensed the
world, and then you

have extracted some information
from these sensory inputs, and then you need to plan what
the next action of your robot

has to be. That's the job of planning. So again, it's a collection
of algorithms and machine learning models that
determine the next action.

And then the final step
is the control, which is-- OK. From the planning, you've
decided what to do next.

But you need to
translate that decision to basically as
inputs or signals

that you give to the
actuators of your robot so that it does the
action that you want. So if it's a vehicle,
the control basically

gives you some steering
input for the steering wheel and some acceleration or
deceleration for the car.

If it's, say, a
drone, it's like, OK, how do you want to change
the propelling forces

of the engines and so on? So this is the conventional
autonomy stack.

And our course, E259, we
basically sit down here. So we are going to
cover all of sensing

and a little bit of perception. Not a whole lot, but we do touch
on perception a little bit.

OK. So let's talk a
little more in detail about sensing and perception.

So as I said,
perception, the job is to extract meaning
from sensor outputs.

And here are just
two simple examples of how sensing and
perception work.

So the top one, this is
a static environment. And what you see here
is what we call a point

cloud of that environment. It's actually the inside
of a meeting room, OK?

And if I did not show
the side to you-- if I just covered this and
just showed you the point cloud

on the left and asked
you as a human to-- OK, describe what is this.

Can you understand-- can you
extract any meaning from this? And this point cloud, maybe
it comes from, say, a lighter

that you had in the room. So what you would do, you
probably like look at it, pan and zoom around and look
at it from different angles.

And eventually,
some structure is going to strike as
familiar to you, and you might say, oh, I
think this in the middle looks

like a table. And then, oh, there is a
bunch of chairs around it, and there is a
little trash bin here

and some bookshelves
on the wall. So you start extracting
meaningful information

from that at that point
cloud that by itself, it's just an occupancy
grid of points in 3D.

So that's basically
what we call perception. But what is important is
the boundary between sensing

and perception is slightly
blurry in different cases. So the distinction is not
always as clear cut as this,

but that gives you an idea of
what sensing and perception is. Here on the bottom
is another example

from a dynamic environment. So this is taken from
an autonomous vehicle.

And here, what you see
is this little thing in the middle that's basically
the ego of the autonomous

vehicle or the vehicle itself. And what's around it,
you see this point cloud that is generated by a LiDAR
that was mounted on the car.

And then on the top
right, you see the image from a camera that was
mounted on the car.

So the sensory
inputs in this case is the point cloud from the
LiDAR, and some camera frames.

And here, what your
perception system does is that it uses
these sensory inputs

and tries to detect and
classify different types of dynamic objects
around the car.

So here, you see these blue
green-ish bounding boxes around vehicles that
were on the street,

and there's quite a lot
of them, and then it also detected a couple of cyclists. So those are these
little purple thingies.

And it detected a
bunch of obstacles. I can't quite tell from the
images, but maybe it was--

I don't know, a fence or
some building or something, and those are colored in gray.

And also, it's a
little bit hard to see, but if you look at it
on a better display,

you would see little
arrows coming out of each of these bounding
boxes for the vehicles. And those are the velocity
vectors that the perception

system detected for different
vehicles around our car. So you see here, we
go from something

that is just pure images
and points in 2D or 3D to something that has a
lot of tangible, actionable

information for autonomy,
which is bounding boxes, trajectories, velocity vectors,
different types of classes

of objects around us,
and so on and so forth. So that's basically
the job of perception.

We would not go quite as deep
into how we do bounding boxes and how we do like
these classifications.

That's not part of our
course, but some functions of perception, as
I said, we will

we'll touch on a little
bit throughout the course. OK.

Next up. I also want to briefly
touch on what is called

the modern autonomy stack. So that for level stack
that we just talked about,

which was sensing,
perception, planning, control, that is called the
conventional autonomy stack.

And 95% of the actual
autonomous robotic products

you see around us
today are built on the conventional
autonomy stack.

Like robotaxis that
you see around us, those are almost entirely using
the conventional autonomous

stack. But as I said, the
conventional autonomy stack has not yet led to unconditional
autonomy as a scale.

We have been at it
for almost 20 years. Still, there is-- we're
not quite there yet.

So some researchers and
also folks in the industry believe that we need to
re-architect this stack.

There is some fundamental
issues that really prohibit this type of architecture from
solving autonomy at scale,

and that's where this idea
of the modern autonomy stack comes up with. And unlike the
conventional thing,

the modern autonomy stack is
still very, very active area of research. So there is no single
incarnation of it

that I could show, but there
is some characteristics that people are
talking about when

they talk about
when they consider the modern autonomy stack. And the characteristics are--

one is basically
using more learning based as opposed to
rule based basically

functions in perception,
planning, and control and even sensing.

Some people talk
about less modularity. So instead of having this
very clear cut distinction

from sensing to perception
to planning to control, have it be more like an
end-to-end model that takes

And before we talk

navigation a little bit. So navigation, as I
said, is the science

of getting a person or a craft
or a vehicle from one location to another. And as we said, it
requires three things.

You require mapping, you
require localization, and you require odometry.

So simple navigation,
like how we people navigate the environments
we use our eyes or we use some landmarks.

There's a building there,
there's a road there, and we use that to build up
our own local map and navigate.

But more complex
navigation, navigation for robots in environments
that no maps exist,

requires some sort of aids. And it could be radio
waves, for instance,

or beacons that we
transmit to these robots and then help them to
localize themselves

within the environment, and
then use that localization information to be
able to navigate.

So these are called
radial navigation waves. And then the user can compute
their position and velocity

by processing the information
they receive from these radio

navigation signals. There's two types of
radio navigations. There's ground based where you
have these ground stations that

transmit radio waves, and
you can use those beacons to localize yourself.

And there is space based
where you use satellites that orbit the Earth, and
then you transmit signals

from these satellites
and use those signals as the aids that help
you localize yourself.

So a GPS or a global
positioning system basically provides localization
and some limited odometry.

So it basically covers
these two functions-- localization and a little
bit of odometer tree, and it

uses satellite radio
navigation signals, OK? So you can do mapping with GPS.

But if you have a map, then

This is the first time

some transmitter,

a signal, in this case,

your watch basically

or whatever that has
a GPS receiver in it. And the concept is,
how do you measure

the range or the distance from
your receiver to the satellite or to the transmitter?

And this is a very
simple concept. If both of these guys, the
receiver and the transmitter,

have a clock that has
been synchronized--

so they align their
clocks or timers. And then if the receiver--
say the transmitter tells you,

I'm going to transmit a
signal at exactly 12:00,

and then you wait to
receive that signal. And as soon as you receive
it, you check your clock

and it says 12 or
6 seconds past 12.

That 6 seconds--
assuming your clocks were perfectly synchronized,
is the time of flight

or is the time that
it took that signal to get from the transmitter
to the receiver.

So that's what we call
the time of flight or T. And if you multiply that by the
speed at which the signal was

traveling-- so in this
case, if it's a radio wave, it's going to travel at
the speed of light, which

is precisely this number or
roughly 300,000 kilometers per second in free space.

So you multiply the time
of flight by the speed, and that gives you the range.

Very, very simple concept. So all you need is a
clock and a knowledge

or two clocks that
are synchronized and the knowledge of the speed
at which your signal travels.

So this satellite

The second satellite is going
to define your position needs to be on the second circle. And the two circles are going
to intersect at two points, A

and B. So you're going to be

of flight measurements,

you reduce your
position uncertainty from infinity, which is you
had no idea where you are

and this 2D plane,
to just two points. So it's pretty

But still, it's ambiguous. You can't tell are

One is, you can add

Another way you can

For instance, if

of the two points

But in 3D, basically, it's the
same principle of operation.

So instead of circles

So if you know the position,

And then the two spheres-- if

This is this dark

flight measurements from two satellites. If you add one more
satellite, so three satellites

in 3D space, they will

of three satellites. And then on top of that, if you

then you basically reduce it

Super, super simple. Now, one thing to note that

That's the ideal case. In the real case, you're going

like triangular

That's your measurement error
